sections.title: Gentle children’s check-ups in Shoreham-by-Sea
sections.body: Friendly visits that cover a soft exam, decay risk review, and simple brushing coaching so children feel confident about their teeth.
bullets: Tell-show-do explanations with space for questions
Short, positive appointments that build trust
Fluoride and diet guidance tailored to your child
Support for baby and adult teeth as they come through

sections.title: Calm, prevention-first care for young patients
items: Regular dentists and hygienists who explain each step in child-friendly language
Tell-show-do with choices like sitting in the chair or on a parent’s lap for the first visit
Flexible pacing — shorter appointments and breaks if a child is nervous
Evidence-based fluoride and diet advice with practical handouts
Clear guidance for knocks, chips, or sore first molars so you know when to call

sections.title: Gentle exams with useful tips for home
sections.body: Each visit focuses on comfort and clear feedback. We check how teeth and gums are developing, talk through decay risk, and coach on brushing together so routines feel achievable.
bullets: Soft look at teeth, gums, and bite including new first molars
Plaque and decay risk review with tailored recall timing
Brushing technique coaching for parents and children
Discussion of fluoride strength and varnish options
Diet and sugar-frequency guidance that fits school and home routines
Notes on habits like thumb sucking, nail biting, or grinding

sections.title: Simple steps that protect baby and adult teeth
sections.body: We share clear prevention plans, from fluoride use to diet tweaks, so families can keep decay risk low. Where suitable, we may suggest fissure sealants for deep grooves in molars to make brushing easier.
bullets: Age-appropriate fluoride toothpaste and varnish guidance
Sugar-frequency advice with realistic snack swaps
Fissure sealants for new molars when clinically helpful
Brushing routines, timers, and disclosing tips
Mouthguard and trauma advice for sport or active play

sections.title: Care for little teeth, growing smiles, and nervous visitors
items: First visits once the first tooth appears or by age one
Children in mixed dentition needing guidance on new molars
Nervous children who benefit from short, positive appointments
Early signs of decay, white spots, or enamel defects
Habits like thumb sucking, bottle-to-bed, or nail biting
Kids with chips or bumps who need monitoring after dental trauma

sections.title: Steady steps that build confidence
items: Welcome and tell-show-do to familiarise your child with the room
Gentle exam of teeth, gums, first molars, and bite development
Brushing and diet coaching with age-appropriate fluoride advice
Preventative care such as varnish or fissure sealants when indicated
Clear recall plan — often 6–12 months depending on risk
Advice for urgent issues like chips or toothache with guidance on when to call
Referral for orthodontic assessment if spacing, crowding, or bite needs a closer look
sections.strapline: We keep visits short and positive, with the option to pause or stage care if a child is anxious.

sections.title: Tools and pacing designed for younger patients
sections.body: We use small instruments, topical numbing gels when needed, and calm language to keep visits comfortable. Parents are kept involved so children know what to expect and feel safe.

sections.title: Know what to watch and when to call
items: Deep grooves in first molars can trap plaque — fissure sealants may reduce risk
Chips or trauma from sport need prompt advice; store any tooth fragment in milk and contact us
Early decay or white spots can often be stabilised with fluoride and diet changes
Habits like thumb sucking, bottle-to-bed, or nail biting can affect bite and enamel
Crowding or bite concerns may lead to a suggestion for an orthodontic assessment
Fluoride use and brushing supervision should continue even when visits are calm
Call if pain, swelling, or sensitivity appears between check-ups

faqs.question: When should my child first visit?
faqs.answer: We recommend a first visit when the first tooth appears or by their first birthday. It keeps things relaxed and lets us share early brushing and diet advice.

faqs.question: How often should children be seen?
faqs.answer: Most children are seen every 6–12 months depending on decay risk and home care. We adjust intervals for higher-risk teeth, first molars, or after any trauma.

faqs.question: Do baby teeth really matter?
faqs.answer: Yes. Healthy baby teeth help children eat, speak, and hold space for adult teeth. Protecting them lowers the chance of pain, infection, and crowding later on.

faqs.question: What if my child is scared?
faqs.answer: We go slowly, use tell-show-do, and keep visits short with breaks. Parents can stay close, and we frame everything positively so children feel in control.

faqs.question: When would you suggest an orthodontic opinion?
faqs.answer: If we see crowding, bite concerns, or early tooth wear, we may recommend an orthodontic assessment so you have a clear plan, even if treatment is not needed yet.

sections.title: Book a calm children’s check-up
sections.body: We’ll keep the visit relaxed, share prevention tips, and guide you if any follow-up is needed.
